Alumni Roll Call Produces
Record-Breaking Results
A check for $166,000 was presented to the University by the
Executive Committee of the 1955
Annual Roll Call at the Commemoration Day exercises last Wednesday.
This gift, the largest yet, represented the contributions of the
alumni during the past year toward the support of the Johns
Hopkins University.
In his report Edwin B. Jarrett,
chairman of the committee, urges
the public not to forget "that this
consistent, increasing interest and
support plays an important role

The Homewood division of the
University figured prominently in
the Roll Call. The undergraduate
school had 3400 donors and contributed a total of $56,000; the
graduate school had 1800 donors
and contributions amounting to
$17,600.
In the distribution of the gifts,
the Homewood Schools received
$23,500, 14.2% of the total. Complete statistics of the Roll Call
will appear in the next issue of

Renewal of the Cotillion Board
Scholarship was the first action
taken by the organization since
the recent election of Norm Vander Noot as president and Bill
Daiger as business manager.
Vander Noot, stated that the
Cotillion Board will donate $100
to the Scholarship Committee.
Selection of the awardee will be
made by Dean Shaffer and will
be based on the financial need,
scholastic standing, and previous
intere`st in extra-curricular activities in pre-college schooling.
Stimulate Interest
The expressed purpose of the
scholarship is to stimulate interest in campus activities and to
provide assistance for an incoming freshman.
Vander Noot stated, "This
scholarship may be used to supplement partial aid already grant-

ed by the Scholarship Committee.
Only the president of the Cotillion Board will know to whom the
scholarship will be awarded in
order to avoid any embarrassment
about the fact that the person is
receiving financial aid."
Students who wish to apply
for the award may do so during
the period announced by the
Scholarship Committee.
An announcement was also
made by Vander Noot concerning

Hi -

the Spring Cotillion Dance, which
is scheduled to be held on March
24. "The purpose of the dance is
to provide an informal dance during the time when there are so
many formals," said Vander Noot.
Tickets will go on sale sometime in the near future. Announcements of the new Freshman members elected to the
Board will be made during the
intermission of the dance.

General Electric is made up of more than
90 product departments that operate as individual "businesses" — each conducting its
own legal, financial, manufacturing, engineering, marketing and research activities.
One of the most important of these businesses is the Technical Products Department
that makes broadcasting and communications equipment and semi-conductor devices.
Responsible for managing the finances of
this $40 million business is Robert H. Platt.
Platt's Work Is Important, Responsible
In the next ten years, the Technical Products
Department is expected to reach the $100
million mark—more than doubling its
present size. This is a big job. And it requires
Platt to keep tabs on everything from tax,
cost, and general accounting to payrolls,
budgets and measurements, credits and collections, and internal auditing.
25,000 College Graduates at General Electric
Experience gained in the Business Training
Course and as a traveling auditor gave Platt
a variety of financial experience. Like each
of our 25,000 college-graduate employees,
he was given the chance to grow and realize
his full potential. For General Electric has
long believed this: When fresh young minds
are given the freedom to make progress,
everybody benefits — the individual, the
company, the country.
Educational Relations, General Electric
Company, Schenectady 5, New York

ROBERT H. PLATT joined G.E. in 1941
after receiving his B.A. at, Colgate
University. He served 2 years in the
Navy,attaining the rank of Lieutenant
(J.G.). He is also a graduate of G.E.'s
Business Training Course.

Art Department No Longer Editors Air Pro
To Award Ph D Howland In Re: Stoning

"We can't accept additional
Ph.D. candidates and haven't
since the fall, although we have
two or three still 'in the mill',"
Dr. Richard Howland, chairman
of the Art Department, stated this
week. He explained, "We have
limited funds for expansion, and
without expansion we cannot of-

ment "may go .. . (since) it has
long been the policy of the Hopkins either to maintain a department as one of the strongest in

HE development of a new airplane such as the Crusader, the World's Fastest
Navy Fighter, cannot be credited to any one engineer. Each engineer, how-

T

ever, is invaluable because this truly new high-performance airplane is only the
final result of the creative thought and teamwork of a large number of engineers.
The individual ideas of each engineer are most
important. In aircraft design, the time lag between
discovery and the utilization of knowledge is
extremely short, shorter perhaps than in any other
major industry. The solutions to the most stimulating problems which arise in the industry are
frequently dependent upon the daily utilization of
new ideas and new knowledge.
The graduating engineer considering his first
career decision may choose whether he will enter
this field of work — the design of airplanes and
missiles — that progresses hand in hand with new
discoveries in all facets of science and engineering,
or choose a less aggressive industry. Of course, it
follows logically that greater and more rapid advancement opportunities lie in a field that does not
stagnate, in a field that is bounded by the creative
imagination of man alone. At Chance Vought, aircraft design draws capable engineers to positions
of greater responsibility in developing new ideas
and supervising the additional technical manpower
needed to "practicalize" the ideas. Starting salaries are commensurate with education and experience for particular specialization and are also
competitive with other industries as well as
other companies. Advancement, as one would

expect, is based upon demonstrated performance,
not seniority.
The future of the aircraft industry is equal to, if
not brighter than, that of other industries. The
complexity of modern aircraft and missiles, the
investigation of new fields of knowledge as aircraft fly higher and faster, the possibilities of
man's further use of science and engineering for
conquest of the air in the second half of the 20th
century, all emphasize the challenge and opportunity to the young graduate.
We urge the graduating engineer to investigate
these opportunities at Chance Vought. He will
find a stable, 38-year-old aircraft designer and
builder with young ideas, a designer and builder
noted for advancing the state-of-the-art of aircraft and guided missile design. He will discover
that Chance Vought offers career opportunities,
not merely impressive titles, and that he will
join an engineering organization that thinks
and operates as a team rather than as a random
collection of individual engineers.
We have the usual fringe benefits including an excellent graduate study program, group insurance,
retirement income plan, paid vacation, sick leave,
moving allowance, and numerous paid holidays.

We invite you to discuss your opportunities at Chance Vought with
W. G. Redmond
who will interview

of the class of '56
in the Placement Office on

Approximately four times each
year, those among us who consider ourselves to be literary and
have for that reason had our
names included on mailing lists
of various used book dealers, receive by post exclusive lists of the
latest bargains and "finds" in the
used book field.
Accompanying these lists, of
course are the prices of each
masterpiece specially reduced for
clearance. As often as not, these
prices are based on such criteria
as the condition, quality, and general overall aesthetic appeal of
the cover and binding, exactly
how outdated the text is, and the
number of pages encompassed by
the work. (Incidentally, yellowed
pages invariably bring higher
prices.)

For the benefit of those around
the Hopkins campus who have
been debating with themselves
the merits and demerits of visiting the Goodwillie Room to inspect the library duplicates which
are now on sale there, we have
composed a list similar to that
distributed by professional book
peddlers. Although merely a sample, and by no means an attempt
at a complete catalogue, we hope
that it will aid in the decision of
"to browse or not to bro—se."

affairs is John Gunther's tome
on our neighbors to the south,

being sacrificed for one dollar.

description of the nobility, gentry,
and fashionable courtesans whom
he encountered as told by him•
self." This is being offered thill
week for only 75 cents.

can be had now for only two dol-

lars.

By BOB MARTINI
Aiming at a spot in the MasonDixon Conference basketball
tournament, the Hopkins ca,gers
travel to Westminster tomorrow
night to play Western Maryland
in the final game of the season
for the Jays.
Hopkins Coach Ross Sachs is
looking for a reversal of the form
which saw the Blue Jays bow to
the Westminster crew by a 72-63
score in an earlier game played at
Homewood. Western Maryland
dwells in next-to-last place in the
torrid Mason-Dixon chase, but
most of their losses have been by
close scores and Sac:is feels that
the Green Terrors will provide a
stern test for the Jays.
The Terrors, Sachs says, are a
ball club improved over early season, due chiefly to the readmittance to the roster of Center Bill
Sparr, who was ineligible for play
in the first half of the campaign.
Sparr was high man with 16 points
in the Terrors' earlier victory.
Other standouts for Western
Maryland include Hugh McIntyre, who is one of the top scorers in the state, Denny Harmon,
and Dusty Martinell.
. Jays Win
The Blue Jays ended their fourgame losing string last week when
they pounced on Rutgers and
downed the Scarlet, 75-65. Guard
Bill Civiletti led the Jay attack
with 25 counters and was followed
by Tom Hollingsworth with 16
and Jim Spitznas with 11. Rutgers placed five men in double figures but no single performer was
able to net more than 13 points.
In their next game, the Jays
downed Randolph-Macon, 77-67,
to run their Mason-Dixon record

Located on the bank of the Connecticut River
at East Hartford is a singular development facility—the Andrew Willgoos Turbine Laboratory.
Here, behind windowless, thick concrete walls,
many types of engineers find a never-ending
challenge in the development and testing of
advanced aircraft engines.
Test methods used by Pratt & Whitney Aircraft in their unique laboratory are highly complex. Tests are conducted on full-scale experimental engines at simulated altitudes up to
76,000 feet. Extremely high speed airflow, with
pressure and temperature accurately controlled,
duplicates speeds as high as Mach 2.75. To reproduce such prodigious flight conditions, extraordinary equipment had to be devised. For
example, a 21,500-hp driving dynamometer supplies the enormous power needed to test jet
engine compressors over a range of speeds from
800 rpm to 16,000 rpm.
The time lapse between development and
production of new engines is reduced considerably by the advanced facilities of the Willgoos
Laboratory. An outstanding example of results
achieved through concentrated engineering effort and complete research support is the Pratt
& Whitney Aircraft J-57 turbojet. Today the
unchallenged leader in its field, the J-57 is
merely the forerunner of greater aircraft engines
that will power the preeminent military and
commercial aircraft of the future.

Andrew Willgoos Turbine Laboratory where jet engines and their components are explored.
Cooling water from the Connecticut River can be pumped through a maze of conduits at
2 times the consumption of a city of half
the rate of 160,000 gallons per minute — 31/
a million people.

the bomb bay. Its regular engines are idled while in-flight performance of the turb•vt is

NEWS -LETTER

Dr. Morgan To Resign In 1957 Leaders Meetings
Return To Campus
To Devote Full Time To Writing
Under ODK Plan
By GORDON SCHOCHET
Professor Clifford T. Morgan,
member of the Department of
Psychology, has announced that
he will resign from the Hopkins
faculty after the first term of
the 1956-57 academic year in order to devote full time to his writings.
Professor Morgan has been a
member of the Hopkins faculty
since 1943, and he was appointed
to his present professorship in
1948. At this time, no successor
has been named by the University
administration.
Dr. Morgan said that the reason
for his resignation is a "rather
unique story, but simplified it
amounts to the fact that I hold
two full time jobs; I can't do both,
so I must make a choice between
them." The first, and more obvious
of his full time occupations is
teaching. Dr. Morgan spends his
"spare" tme writing and editing
in the field of psychology. His
fourth book, a text for introductory psychology instruction, will
be published next month and will

be used by the Hopkns Introductory Psychology course next year.
To Revise Books
During the next four years, Dr.
Morgan must also revise his
physiological psychology text book
and begin work on the second
edition of his newest publication.
The first printing of the book will
consist of 50,000 copies.
Both he and the publishers
(McGraw Hill) expect the text to
be "quite successful." According
to Professor Morgan, it is the custom .of his publisher to keep irkstructive books in revision approximately every five years. "All
of this," said Dr. Morgan, "takes
time; the revision must be begun
about three years before it is to
appear on the market."
Professor Morgan also plans to
write a number of other texts in
pschology, but he has no definite
plans concerning them. "Two revisions are enough to keep a man
busy," he said. "The process can
go on and on, so long as the books
are successful. The physiological
and the new book looks as if it
also will meet with success."

Consulting Editor
In addition to teaching and
writing, Dr. Morgan is consulting
editor for the McGraw Hill
psychology series. This job means
that he must read and consult
with the publishers upon all prospective publications.
His withdrawal from the University will be Dr. Morgan's permanent retirement from the teaching profession. He said that he
enjoys teaching, "but I don't like
to make it a full time job. I also
enjoy writing, so I had to make
a choice." He resigned as Chairman of the Psychology Department in June, 1954, n order to
have more time to devote to his
forthcoming publication which
was six years in preparation.
Professor Morgan now lives in
Cambridge, Maryland, or a shorefront farm he has owned for the
past two years. The farm was
bought in anticipation of his resignation, and he will do all of
his future work there. At the time
the farm waS- purchased, Dr. Morgan was not sure that he would
resign from the faculty.

Under the sponsorship of ODK,
national leadership fraternity,
Meetings of campus leaders, discontinued last year "because of
their inability to work", were renewed yesterday under a newly
devised plan, according to ODK
President Herbert Belgrad.
Yestereay's meeting comprised
the leaders of the various student
public relations groups on the
campus. The series.of meetings,
conducted in three parts, will
continue next Thursday with a
meeting of the heads of leadership organizations, and on the
following Thursday with a meeting of the leaders of the various
campus social groups.

was acquitted of an alleged
violation, which was reported
to have occurred during final
examinations, at a recent Honor Commission Trial.

Renewal of the Cotillion Board
Scholarship was the first action
taken by the organization since
the recent election of Norm Vander Noot as president and Bill
Daiger as business manager.
Vander Noot, stated that the
Cotillion Board will donate $100
to the Scholarship Committee.
Selection of the awardee will be
made by Dean Shaffer and will
be based on the financial need,
scholastic standing, and previous
intere`st in extra-curricular activities in pre-college schooling.
Stimulate Interest
The expressed purpose of the
scholarship is to stimulate interest in campus activities and to
provide assistance for an incoming freshman.
Vander Noot stated, "This
scholarship may be used to supplement partial aid already grant-

ed by the Scholarship Committee.
Only the president of the Cotillion Board will know to whom the
scholarship will be awarded in
order to avoid any embarrassment
about the fact that the person is
receiving financial aid."
Students who wish to apply
for the award may do so during
the period announced by the
Scholarship Committee.
An announcement was also
made by Vander Noot concerning

Hi -

the Spring Cotillion Dance, which
is scheduled to be held on March
24. "The purpose of the dance is
to provide an informal dance during the time when there are so
many formals," said Vander Noot.
Tickets will go on sale sometime in the near future. Announcements of the new Freshman members elected to the
Board will be made during the
intermission of the dance.

General Electric is made up of more than
90 product departments that operate as individual "businesses" — each conducting its
own legal, financial, manufacturing, engineering, marketing and research activities.
One of the most important of these businesses is the Technical Products Department
that makes broadcasting and communications equipment and semi-conductor devices.
Responsible for managing the finances of
this $40 million business is Robert H. Platt.
Platt's Work Is Important, Responsible
In the next ten years, the Technical Products
Department is expected to reach the $100
million mark—more than doubling its
present size. This is a big job. And it requires
Platt to keep tabs on everything from tax,
cost, and general accounting to payrolls,
budgets and measurements, credits and collections, and internal auditing.
25,000 College Graduates at General Electric
Experience gained in the Business Training
Course and as a traveling auditor gave Platt
a variety of financial experience. Like each
of our 25,000 college-graduate employees,
he was given the chance to grow and realize
his full potential. For General Electric has
long believed this: When fresh young minds
are given the freedom to make progress,
everybody benefits — the individual, the
company, the country.
Educational Relations, General Electric
Company, Schenectady 5, New York

ROBERT H. PLATT joined G.E. in 1941
after receiving his B.A. at, Colgate
University. He served 2 years in the
Navy,attaining the rank of Lieutenant
(J.G.). He is also a graduate of G.E.'s
Business Training Course.

HE development of a new airplane such as the Crusader, the World's Fastest
Navy Fighter, cannot be credited to any one engineer. Each engineer, how-

T

ever, is invaluable because this truly new high-performance airplane is only the
final result of the creative thought and teamwork of a large number of engineers.
The individual ideas of each engineer are most
important. In aircraft design, the time lag between
discovery and the utilization of knowledge is
extremely short, shorter perhaps than in any other
major industry. The solutions to the most stimulating problems which arise in the industry are
frequently dependent upon the daily utilization of
new ideas and new knowledge.
The graduating engineer considering his first
career decision may choose whether he will enter
this field of work — the design of airplanes and
missiles — that progresses hand in hand with new
discoveries in all facets of science and engineering,
or choose a less aggressive industry. Of course, it
follows logically that greater and more rapid advancement opportunities lie in a field that does not
stagnate, in a field that is bounded by the creative
imagination of man alone. At Chance Vought, aircraft design draws capable engineers to positions
of greater responsibility in developing new ideas
and supervising the additional technical manpower
needed to "practicalize" the ideas. Starting salaries are commensurate with education and experience for particular specialization and are also
competitive with other industries as well as
other companies. Advancement, as one would

expect, is based upon demonstrated performance,
not seniority.
The future of the aircraft industry is equal to, if
not brighter than, that of other industries. The
complexity of modern aircraft and missiles, the
investigation of new fields of knowledge as aircraft fly higher and faster, the possibilities of
man's further use of science and engineering for
conquest of the air in the second half of the 20th
century, all emphasize the challenge and opportunity to the young graduate.
We urge the graduating engineer to investigate
these opportunities at Chance Vought. He will
find a stable, 38-year-old aircraft designer and
builder with young ideas, a designer and builder
noted for advancing the state-of-the-art of aircraft and guided missile design. He will discover
that Chance Vought offers career opportunities,
not merely impressive titles, and that he will
join an engineering organization that thinks
and operates as a team rather than as a random
collection of individual engineers.
We have the usual fringe benefits including an excellent graduate study program, group insurance,
retirement income plan, paid vacation, sick leave,
moving allowance, and numerous paid holidays.

We invite you to discuss your opportunities at Chance Vought with
W. G. Redmond
who will interview

of the class of '56
in the Placement Office on

Goodwillie Bibliophile Mecca
Approximately four times each
year, those among us who consider ourselves to be literary and
have for that reason had our
names included on mailing lists
of various used book dealers, receive by post exclusive lists of the
latest bargains and "finds" in the
used book field.
Accompanying these lists, of
course are the prices of each
masterpiece specially reduced for
clearance. As often as not, these
prices are based on such criteria
as the condition, quality, and general overall aesthetic appeal of
the cover and binding, exactly
how outdated the text is, and the
number of pages encompassed by
the work. (Incidentally, yellowed
pages invariably bring higher
prices.)

For the benefit of those around
the Hopkins campus who have
been debating with themselves
the merits and demerits of visiting the Goodwillie Room to inspect the library duplicates which
are now on sale there, we have
composed a list similar to that
distributed by professional book
peddlers. Although merely a sample, and by no means an attempt
at a complete catalogue, we hope
that it will aid in the decision of
"to browse or not to bro—se."

Foreign Affairs
Representing curre-t foreign
affairs is John Gunther's tome
on our neighbors to the south,
Inside Latin America, which is
being sacrificed for one dollar.
Representing past foreign affairs is a volume of Casanova in

England, "Being an account of
the visit to London in 1763-'4 of
Giacomo Casanova Chevalier de
Seengelt, his schemes, enterpriseS
and amorous adventures with a
description of the nobility, gentry,
and fashionable courtesans whom
he encountered as told by him•
self." This is being offered thill
week for only 75 cents.

Latin and Latin to English lexicography from 1440 to 1736. Although the price "$6.00" is clearly
printed on the overleaf, this in.
valuable and informative text
can be had now for only two dol-

lars.

By BOB MARTINI
Aiming at a spot in the MasonDixon Conference basketball
tournament, the Hopkins ca,gers
travel to Westminster tomorrow
night to play Western Maryland
in the final game of the season
for the Jays.
Hopkins Coach Ross Sachs is
looking for a reversal of the form
which saw the Blue Jays bow to
the Westminster crew by a 72-63
score in an earlier game played at
Homewood. Western Maryland
dwells in next-to-last place in the
torrid Mason-Dixon chase, but
most of their losses have been by
close scores and Sac:is feels that
the Green Terrors will provide a
stern test for the Jays.
The Terrors, Sachs says, are a
ball club improved over early season, due chiefly to the readmittance to the roster of Center Bill
Sparr, who was ineligible for play
in the first half of the campaign.
Sparr was high man with 16 points
in the Terrors' earlier victory.
Other standouts for Western
Maryland include Hugh McIntyre, who is one of the top scorers in the state, Denny Harmon,
and Dusty Martinell.
. Jays Win
The Blue Jays ended their fourgame losing string last week when
they pounced on Rutgers and
downed the Scarlet, 75-65. Guard
Bill Civiletti led the Jay attack
with 25 counters and was followed
by Tom Hollingsworth with 16
and Jim Spitznas with 11. Rutgers placed five men in double figures but no single performer was
able to net more than 13 points.
In their next game, the Jays
downed Randolph-Macon, 77-67,
to run their Mason-Dixon record
to 5-3. After leading by 15-10 following the first &yen minutes of
play, the Black and Blue increased
their liftcl to ten points, only to
have the Yellow Jackets cut it
back to 36-31 at the half.
Randolph-Macon came within
three points at 42-39 early in the
second half, but from there the
Jays steadily increased their advantage until they led, 74-58,
with a minute and a half to play.
At this point Coach Sachs put in
a host of Substitutes and the game
ended with the Blue Jays on the
good side of a 10-point spread.

Bill Civiletti came up with his
second consecltive 25-tally performance and was aided by 16
points by Jerry Gottlieb, 13 by
Tom Hollingsworth, and 10 by Al

Located on the bank of the Connecticut River
at East Hartford is a singular development facility—the Andrew Willgoos Turbine Laboratory.
Here, behind windowless, thick concrete walls,
many types of engineers find a never-ending
challenge in the development and testing of
advanced aircraft engines.
Test methods used by Pratt & Whitney Aircraft in their unique laboratory are highly complex. Tests are conducted on full-scale experimental engines at simulated altitudes up to
76,000 feet. Extremely high speed airflow, with
pressure and temperature accurately controlled,
duplicates speeds as high as Mach 2.75. To reproduce such prodigious flight conditions, extraordinary equipment had to be devised. For
example, a 21,500-hp driving dynamometer supplies the enormous power needed to test jet
engine compressors over a range of speeds from
800 rpm to 16,000 rpm.
The time lapse between development and
production of new engines is reduced considerably by the advanced facilities of the Willgoos
Laboratory. An outstanding example of results
achieved through concentrated engineering effort and complete research support is the Pratt
& Whitney Aircraft J-57 turbojet. Today the
unchallenged leader in its field, the J-57 is
merely the forerunner of greater aircraft engines
that will power the preeminent military and
commercial aircraft of the future.

NEWS -LETTER

Dr. Morgan To Resign In 1957 Leaders Meetings
Return To Campus
To Devote Full Time To Writing
Under ODK Plan
By GORDON SCHOCHET
Professor Clifford T. Morgan,
member of the Department of
Psychology, has announced that
he will resign from the Hopkins
faculty after the first term of
the 1956-57 academic year in order to devote full time to his writings.
Professor Morgan has been a
member of the Hopkins faculty
since 1943, and he was appointed
to his present professorship in
1948. At this time, no successor
has been named by the University
administration.
Dr. Morgan said that the reason
for his resignation is a "rather
unique story, but simplified it
amounts to the fact that I hold
two full time jobs; I can't do both,
so I must make a choice between
them." The first, and more obvious
of his full time occupations is
teaching. Dr. Morgan spends his
"spare" tme writing and editing
in the field of psychology. His
fourth book, a text for introductory psychology instruction, will
be published next month and will

be used by the Hopkns Introductory Psychology course next year.
To Revise Books
During the next four years, Dr.
Morgan must also revise his
physiological psychology text book
and begin work on the second
edition of his newest publication.
The first printing of the book will
consist of 50,000 copies.
Both he and the publishers
(McGraw Hill) expect the text to
be "quite successful." According
to Professor Morgan, it is the custom .of his publisher to keep irkstructive books in revision approximately every five years. "All
of this," said Dr. Morgan, "takes
time; the revision must be begun
about three years before it is to
appear on the market."
Professor Morgan also plans to
write a number of other texts in
pschology, but he has no definite
plans concerning them. "Two revisions are enough to keep a man
busy," he said. "The process can
go on and on, so long as the books
are successful. The physiological
and the new book looks as if it
also will meet with success."

Consulting Editor
In addition to teaching and
writing, Dr. Morgan is consulting
editor for the McGraw Hill
psychology series. This job means
that he must read and consult
with the publishers upon all prospective publications.
His withdrawal from the University will be Dr. Morgan's permanent retirement from the teaching profession. He said that he
enjoys teaching, "but I don't like
to make it a full time job. I also
enjoy writing, so I had to make
a choice." He resigned as Chairman of the Psychology Department in June, 1954, n order to
have more time to devote to his
forthcoming publication which
was six years in preparation.
Professor Morgan now lives in
Cambridge, Maryland, or a shorefront farm he has owned for the
past two years. The farm was
bought in anticipation of his resignation, and he will do all of
his future work there. At the time
the farm waS- purchased, Dr. Morgan was not sure that he would
resign from the faculty.

Under the sponsorship of ODK,
national leadership fraternity,
Meetings of campus leaders, discontinued last year "because of
their inability to work", were renewed yesterday under a newly
devised plan, according to ODK
President Herbert Belgrad.
Yestereay's meeting comprised
the leaders of the various student
public relations groups on the
campus. The series.of meetings,
conducted in three parts, will
continue next Thursday with a
meeting of the heads of leadership organizations, and on the
following Thursday with a meeting of the leaders of the various
campus social groups.
